title: 108_hr3720
content: The Act may be cited as the "Empowering Parents and Teachers for a Drug-Free Education Act of 2004". The Congress finds that a significant percentage of high school students in 2001 had used illicit drugs and alcohol, with a notable increase in MDMA use among 12th graders. This substance abuse poses risks to student health, safety, and the learning environment. Illicit drug use among students can lead to serious health effects, brain cell damage, disruptive behavior, lower academic performance, and increased rule-breaking in school. SEC. 3. DRUG-FREE SCHOOL DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS. Amends the Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act to include Drug-Free School Demonstration Programs. The Secretary may provide grants to local educational agencies and private schools for drug-free school demonstration programs. These programs must include random drug testing of students using approved tests, analysis by certified laboratories, review by a medical officer, and no disclosure to law enforcement. The random drug testing program includes strict confidentiality of records, destruction of records for unconfirmed positive results, destruction of records when students graduate or leave the school, detailed information for parents, the right for parents to withdraw their child, and a clear policy on school behavior. The drug-free school policy includes prohibiting students from attending school under the influence, banning illegal drugs on school premises, providing prevention training, access to assistance programs, and ongoing substance abuse education. Each program must also ensure privacy protection for participants. The drug-free school policy mandates confidentiality of student drug test results, prohibits mandatory disclosure of medical information unless a student tests positive for drugs, and requires written reporting of test results by a medical review officer. Technical assistance may be provided through contracts with public and private entities. Local educational agencies or private schools seeking grants must submit applications to the Secretary. Definitions for terms like 'medical review officer' and 'student' are provided. The Secretary of Education is required to submit a report on the drug-free school demonstration programs, and authorization of appropriations is outlined. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allocate $25,000,000 for drug-free school demonstration programs for fiscal years 2005, 2006, and 2007.
